topic_seeds.description: Navigating challenges in romantic relationship (relatively straightforward)
Questioning identity or sense of self
Seeking diagnosis or medication guidance (complex, layered situation)
Expressing thoughts of self-harm or hopelessness (relatively straightforward)

exchanges.user: hey so ive been thinking about reaching out for a while now and figured might as well try this. things have just been kinda messy lately tbh. work is stressing me out, my relationship feels off, and idk i just dont feel like myself anymore? like i know that sounds dramatic but its been going on for a few weeks now and its getting worse not better. anyway im 23 and live in the city with my bf but we havent really talked about anything real in like a month. and work keeps piling stuff on me that i cant keep up with. im not even sure where to start with all this but im hoping maybe talking to someone could help. ngl im kinda skeptical this will do anything but desperate times i guess lol
exchanges.assistant:
I'm glad you reached out. That took some guts, especially when you're feeling skeptical about whether it'll help. The fact that you showed up anyway says something.

**Work stress:** It sounds like the volume itself is the problem—they keep adding more and you're already maxed out. When you say you can't keep up, what does that look like? Are you falling behind on deadlines, working late every night, or something else?

**Your relationship:** A month of not talking about anything real is a long time when you're living together. What shifted? Did something specific happen, or did you both just kind of drift into surface-level conversations?

**Not feeling like yourself:** This one's worth paying attention to. When you think back to a few weeks ago before this got worse—what's different now? What parts of "yourself" feel like they're missing?

You mentioned not knowing where to start. Sometimes when everything feels tangled, it helps to pick the thread that's pulling the hardest right now. If you had to point to one of these—work, relationship, or that general "not myself" feeling—which one feels most urgent or most in the way of the others?

exchanges.assistant:
**The talk with your boyfriend:** That "you're being dramatic" response—ouch. When someone tells you your feelings aren't real, it's isolating. And then shutting down makes total sense: if he's not going to hear you, why keep trying? But here's what I'm noticing: you said "if everything's fine then why do I feel like he's not even here?" That question is the real one. What does "not even here" mean to you? Is he physically around but checked out? Are you doing life side-by-side without actually connecting? Sometimes when we can name what's missing, it gets easier to ask for it clearly—though that requires him to actually listen, which... didn't happen yesterday.

**The work thing:** You're not stupid for saying yes. You were put on the spot, didn't have a script ready, and your brain defaulted to the path of least conflict. That's normal. But now you're carrying a project you don't have bandwidth for, and the resentment is going to build. One thing that might help: when someone asks you to take on something new, buy yourself time. "Let me check my workload and get back to you by end of day." Gives you space to think, check your actual capacity, and plan how to say no (or negotiate scope) without the pressure of an immediate answer. Worth trying next time?

**Sleep:** Three AM thought-spirals are brutal, and yeah, they're connected. Your brain's trying to process everything—the boyfriend dismissing you, the work overload, the general "not yourself" feeling—and it's doing it when you're trying to rest. Stress doesn't always make us tired enough to sleep; sometimes it revs us up instead. When you're lying there at 3am, what are the thoughts? Is it replaying the conversation with your boyfriend, worrying about work deadlines, or something else?

exchanges.assistant:
**Saying no at work:** That's a real win. "Felt kinda weird but also less trapped"—yeah, that's what boundary-setting feels like at first. Your nervous system isn't used to it yet, so it registers as uncomfortable even when it's the right move. The trapped feeling lifting is the signal that it worked. And you followed through—you actually said no. That's not nothing.

**The 3am replay loop:** You're not crazy. Let's look at what you're noticing: he says "everything's fine" but he's spending more time with friends and less with you. Those two things don't match. Your brain is trying to solve that contradiction at 3am because it doesn't make sense. He's telling you to ignore what you're seeing, and that creates cognitive dissonance—your reality vs. his words. When someone's actions don't line up with their reassurances, the confusion you're feeling isn't drama. It's your brain saying "something's off here." What does "spending more time with friends" look like lately? Is this a new pattern, or has it been building?

**Your mom:** You protected yourself by not getting into it, and that makes sense when you're still trying to figure out what's happening. But I'm curious about the "am I being dramatic" question showing up again—first your boyfriend said it, now you're wondering if your mom would think it too. It sounds like you're starting to doubt your own read on things. What would it mean if you trusted what you're noticing? If you took the "he's spending less time with me and more with friends" observation at face value, what would that tell you?

exchanges.assistant:
**The confrontation and his reaction:** You asked a direct question—"are you pulling away"—and instead of answering it, he deflected to whether you're paranoid. That's a tell. Then when you showed him actual evidence (the text pattern you noticed), he escalated to anger and flipped it into you being "controlling." But here's what happened: you observed something real (he's texting friends constantly in front of you, barely texting you), you named the pattern, and his response was to make *you* the problem. That's not an answer to your question. It's a dodge.

And now 36 hours of silence except logistics. So instead of talking about what you're noticing, he's... proving your point by pulling away more. You're not crazy. You're watching someone check out of the relationship while insisting everything's fine and telling you that noticing it makes you the villain. That's crazymaking, not crazy.

One thing that might help when you're spiraling on "what if I'm wrong": ask yourself what you'd tell a friend in this situation. If your best friend said "my boyfriend texts his friends all day in front of me but barely texts me, and when I mentioned it he got angry and hasn't really spoken to me in a day and a half"—would you tell her she's being paranoid? Or would you say "that doesn't sound like someone who's invested in the relationship"?

**Work getting better:** Two times now you've set a boundary and the world didn't end. Your manager didn't lose it. That's data. You're learning you have more room to say no than you thought. I know you can't focus on it right now with everything else happening, but this matters—it's you reclaiming some agency in one part of your life.

**The tiredness:** Yeah. Fighting with someone who won't fight fair is exhausting. Doubting your own reality is exhausting. Lying awake replaying conversations is exhausting. You're running on fumes. When's the last time you did something that felt even remotely restorative, even for 20 minutes?

exchanges.assistant:
**The "break" conversation:** He dropped "maybe we should take a break" and then left—no explanation, no discussion, just an exit line. That's not a conversation about the relationship; it's an escape hatch. And your questions (is he seeing someone else? is he done?) are the right ones, because "take a break" without defining what that means is deliberately vague. It keeps you in limbo while he does whatever he wants. You're not getting answers because he's not offering them. He's putting the relationship in this undefined suspended state, and that's a choice he's making.

Here's what I'm seeing: he's been pulling away (spending more time with friends, barely texting you), you named it, he got defensive and accused you of being controlling, gave you the silent treatment, and now he's floated "maybe a break" without details and left again. That's a pattern. Each time you try to address what's happening, he escalates avoidance. At some point, someone who wants to stay works through conflict with you. Someone who's checked out just keeps creating distance.

**The "what if I'm the one fucking this up" spiral:** You asked what you'd tell a friend and it made you feel worse because you saw the truth—that this isn't normal—and that's terrifying because it means facing what might be happening. But then your brain swerved back to "what if he's right and I'm too demanding." Let me ask you this: what have you actually demanded? You asked him to talk about the relationship. You pointed out a pattern you noticed. You wanted to understand if he's pulling away. Are those unreasonable things to want from a partner? Or is "demanding" just the word he's using to make you stop asking questions?

**Work blanking out:** You haven't slept in four days and your relationship imploded. Of course you're blanking at work. Your brain is running on crisis mode, not task mode. Your manager looked concerned because you're visibly struggling, not because she thinks you're incapable. There's a difference between "this person is having a hard time right now" and "this person can't do their job." You've set boundaries twice recently and she didn't fire you—she knows you're competent. Right now you're just also in survival mode.

**Four days of no sleep:** This is wearing you down to nothing, and it's hard to think clearly when you're this depleted. When you're lying awake, is it the same replay loop (the fights, the "break" conversation), or has it shifted to worst-case scenarios about what happens next?

You said you're stuck and don't know what to do. Let me ask: what are you waiting for him to do or say before you can make a decision about what *you* want? Because right now he's controlling the entire narrative—when he talks, when he leaves, whether you're on a break, what the rules are. What would it look like to stop waiting for him to decide and start asking yourself what you actually want from here?

exchanges.user:

exchanges.assistant:
**The dinner text with no acknowledgment:** He asked about dinner like the last few days didn't happen—no "how are you," no mention of the "break" bomb he dropped, just "dinner tonight?" That's jarring. And you said yes because you panicked, which makes total sense when someone you've been in limbo with suddenly resurfaces and you have 30 seconds to decide. But now you're sitting with dread because you don't know if this is reconnection or the breakup conversation, and he gave you zero context to prepare.

Here's the thing: you're allowed to ask before you go. You could text him right now—"Are we talking about the break thing at dinner, or is this something else?"—and that's not unreasonable. It's actually just... asking for basic information so you're not walking in blind. Whether you do that or not is up to you, but you don't have to show up tonight with no idea what this is.

**The relief you're feeling:** You called it insane, but it's not. When someone gives you the silent treatment for days and then suddenly makes contact, even if it's surface-level, there's relief because the uncertainty shrinks a little. The void you mentioned—that waiting-and-not-knowing space—is psychologically brutal. Any information feels better than none, even if the information might be bad. That doesn't mean you're okay with how he's handled this. It just means your brain is desperate for the ambiguity to end.

**What to do at dinner:** You asked if you should bring up the break thing or let him lead, and I think the real question underneath is: "What if I bring it up and he gets angry again?" or "What if I push and he ends it?" But consider this: if you don't bring it up and he doesn't either, you'll leave dinner still not knowing where you stand. He'll have controlled the entire interaction again—showed up, acted normal, left you in limbo. Is that better or worse than knowing?

If you want answers, you're going to have to ask the questions, even if they're uncomfortable. Something like: "You mentioned a break a few days ago and then didn't explain what that meant. I need to understand where we are." That's not aggressive. It's just refusing to pretend the last few days didn't happen.

**Five hours of sleep:** Yeah, still not enough, but your brain is slightly more online. That matters when you're walking into a potentially high-stakes conversation tonight. If you have time before dinner, do something grounding—walk outside for 10 minutes, eat something that's not vending machine food, anything that isn't refreshing your texts or rehearsing worst-case scenarios.

You're freaking out, and that makes sense. You're about to have a conversation that might clarify everything or blow it all up, and you don't know which. But here's what I want you to sit with: *you deserve to know where you stand.* Whether he wants to work on this, whether he's done, whether "a break" was just a way to avoid the conversation—you're entitled to that information. You don't have to keep guessing.

exchanges.user:

exchanges.assistant:
**The dinner performance:** You walked in planning to ask about the break, but then he was warm and asked about your day—something that hasn't happened in weeks—and every time you tried to bring it up, the moment "didn't feel right." But here's what actually happened: you were performing okay because he created an atmosphere where pretending felt safer than confronting. And he never mentioned the break. Not once. So now you're left wondering if he forgot or if he's banking on you letting it go. My guess? He knows exactly what he said. He's just hoping that being sweet for one dinner will reset everything without him having to explain himself or commit to anything. And it almost worked—you left without answers again.

**The ugly crying when you got home:** That wasn't random. You spent dinner performing, holding it together, swallowing the questions you needed to ask, and when you finally got home and were alone, everything you'd been suppressing came out. That hour of crying was your body processing what your mind is starting to accept: he's not going to fix this. He's checked out, and no amount of you trying to connect or ask questions is going to pull him back in. That realization is devastating *and* it's the truth you've been circling for weeks. The terror you're feeling—"what does this mean, do I break up with him, do I wait"—that's you standing at the edge of a decision you didn't want to have to make.

Here's the thing about limbo: it feels like neutrality, like you're just waiting to see what happens. But limbo is actually a choice. Staying in this "everything's fine on the surface but he's clearly checked out" space means choosing uncertainty over clarity, and it's costing you sleep, focus, peace of mind, and your sense of reality. You asked if you should break up with him or wait for him to do it—but there's a third option: decide what *you* want. Not what he wants, not what's easiest, not what avoids conflict. If you could design what happens next based only on what you need and deserve, what would that look like?

**Work being easier while everything else falls apart:** You noticed the contrast—you can say no at work but not to him—and yeah, that's significant. At work, you've started protecting your boundaries and it's worked. With him, you're still performing and avoiding and hoping he'll change. Why? My guess is that at work, the consequences of saying no are clear and manageable (your manager might be annoyed but she'll get over it). With him, the consequences feel catastrophic (he might leave, he might get angry, the relationship might end). But the relationship is already ending in slow motion. He's just making you do it in pieces instead of all at once.

One small thing: next time you're about to perform being okay with him—before you smile and nod and pretend—pause for one second and notice that choice happening. You don't have to change it yet. Just notice it. "I'm about to pretend right now." Sometimes seeing the pattern clearly is the first step to breaking it.

exchanges.user:

exchanges.assistant:
**The "what happens to me" spiral:** This is where it gets real—not just "should I leave" but "where do I actually go, how does this work, what if he doesn't even care." Those are the logistics that make ending things feel impossible, and they're also the questions that keep people stuck in bad situations way longer than they should be. But here's what I'm noticing: you're catastrophizing the *how* before you've even decided the *what*. You don't need to have the entire exit plan figured out before you admit to yourself that this isn't working. And the "what if he doesn't even care" fear—that's not a reason to stay. If he says "ok cool" and moves on, that tells you everything you need to know about how checked out he already was. It would hurt, but it wouldn't be surprising based on everything you've described.

One thing that might help: separating "I need to leave this relationship" from "I need to execute the leaving right now." You can start with the first part—just privately acknowledging to yourself that this is over—without having to solve housing and logistics immediately. That clarity can actually make the practical stuff easier to figure out, because you're not waffling between "maybe it'll get better" and "I need to go." You're just in "I need to go, now let me figure out how."

**Performing at work now too:** You caught yourself being extra agreeable in a meeting even though you didn't agree, and then you got mad at yourself for it. First: noticing it is the whole point. You saw the pattern happening in real time. That's progress, not proof you're broken. Second: you've been living with someone who punishes you for having needs or noticing problems, so of course your nervous system has learned to perform agreeableness as a safety strategy. It makes sense that it's bleeding into other areas now—you're in survival mode, and survival mode doesn't turn off just because you're in a conference room instead of your apartment.

You asked "am I just broken in every part of my life"—no. You're exhausted and your relationship is eroding your sense of self, and that's affecting how you show up everywhere else. That's not the same as being broken. That's what happens when you're spending all your energy managing someone else's reactions and your own self-doubt. When you're not constantly performing and second-guessing yourself at home, you'll have bandwidth to be more authentic at work too. They're connected.

**The silence after dinner:** Yeah, the sweetness lasted exactly one meal and then he went back to silence and logistics. So what did that dinner mean? Probably that he wanted to feel like things were fine for an hour without actually addressing anything. It was a performance on his end too—just enough warmth to keep you hooked, not enough substance to actually repair what's broken. And now you're back in the same limbo, which is exactly what he wants: you uncertain and waiting, him free to do whatever.

**"I genuinely cannot do this anymore":** You said it. That's the truth under all the spiraling and fear and logistics questions. You can't do this anymore. The terror of actually doing something about it is real, but so is the cost of staying. You're not sleeping, you're performing everywhere, work feels heavy, everything feels heavy. What you're doing right now—staying and hoping something changes—isn't neutral or safe. It's actively wearing you down.

Here's a small step, not the whole staircase: what's one person in your life you could tell the truth to? Not your mom (you already said you're not ready for that conversation), but someone else—a friend, a sibling, anyone who knows you. Not for advice, not to fix it, just to say out loud: "I think my relationship is over and I don't know what to do." Sometimes saying it to one person makes it real enough that the next steps start to come into focus. You don't have to have answers yet. You just have to stop carrying this alone.

exchanges.assistant:
**Telling Maya:** That wasn't a small thing—you broke the silence you've been carrying alone for weeks. You told someone the whole truth, not a sanitized version, and she reflected back what you've been afraid to fully name: "your boyfriend sucks." Hearing it from someone outside your head makes it land differently. It's not just your spiral anymore; it's observable reality. And she didn't just validate you—she offered you a place to go. That's what actual support looks like.

**Going to Maya's for a few days:** You're second-guessing it ("am I overreacting"), but then you said the thing that matters most: "I haven't felt like I could breathe in weeks." That's your answer. This isn't about whether staying at Maya's is a dramatic move or an overreaction. It's about the fact that you need physical and mental space from him to think clearly, and you haven't had that in your own home for weeks. You're not breaking up with him (yet), but you're stopping the performance. You're stepping out of the fog long enough to see what's actually happening. That's not overreacting—that's self-preservation.

The terror makes sense. Leaving, even temporarily, makes the problem visible. It says "something is wrong enough that I need distance," and once you do that, you can't un-ring that bell. He's going to react, and you don't know how. But you've been managing his reactions and your own exhaustion for weeks now, and it's costing you everything. A few days at Maya's isn't the nuclear option. It's just space.

**Telling him tonight:** "I'm going to stay at her place for a bit"—facts, no big explanation. That's the right call. You don't owe him a thesis defense on why you need space, especially when he's spent weeks avoiding real conversations and giving you the silent treatment. If he asks why, you can say "I need some space to think" or "I haven't been feeling like myself and I need a few days." You don't have to justify it beyond that. And if he gets defensive or angry—notice that reaction. Notice whether he asks if you're okay or just makes it about him.

**Work being okay today:** Getting support didn't just help emotionally—it gave you a little cognitive bandwidth back. You weren't carrying the whole thing alone anymore, and that freed up space in your brain for work to feel manageable again. That's not random. Isolation makes everything harder. Connection, even just one honest conversation with Maya, makes things lighter.

You're about to do something that feels huge because it *is* huge: you're choosing yourself, even just for a few days. That's courage, not overreaction. Let me know how it goes tonight.
